TopicTitle: KerbalEdu Launches Their First Update With Fully Integrated Educational Features

Articles.Content:
<p><a href="http://www.kerbaledu.com"><span><em><img alt="image" src="https://31.media.tumblr.com/a83db51e2adf71c2480104bb957e8550/tumblr_inline_ngubejYZLu1rr2wit.png"/></em></span></a></p>

<p><span><em>KerbalEdu</em>, an educationally-enhanced modification of the popular, award-winning space agency game, <em>Kerbal Space Program</em>, has launched its first update which fully integrates features that are exclusive to the classroom.</span></p>

<p><span>TeacherGaming, developer of <em>KerbalEdu</em>, as well as the notable <em>MinecraftEdu</em>, have worked alongside Squad, developer of<em> Kerbal Space Program</em>, to ensure that this update not only distinguishes itself as a fun tool for students, but also maintains the spirit of what has made the regular version of the game one of the most popular indie titles today.</span></p>

TeacherGaming takes KSP to the next level and makes the educational aspects as important as the gameplay, if not more so, in the best ways possible. TheyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve modified things to where students can grasp onto some of the gameÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s concepts in an easier, more practical way. Teachers and students are really going to have fun with this.Ã¢â‚¬Â</em></span></p>

<p><span>Among the many notable features in this update are:</span></p>

<ul><li>

<p><strong>Mission Library & Mission Editor: </strong><span>Teachers can create and edit missions .or lesson plans and upload them into the mission library for others to download</span></p>

</li>

</ul><ul><li>

<p><strong>Force Arrows:</strong><span> A part that shows what forces act on a craft during flight using multicolored arrows</span></p>

</li>

</ul><ul><li>

<p><strong>Flight Recorder:</strong><span> View data about flights in graphical form and save them in a variety of file formats</span></p>

</li>

</ul><ul><li>

<p><strong>Function Tool:</strong><span> Evaluate real-time mathematical functions during flight</span></p>

</li>

</ul><ul><li>

<p><strong>Scenarios:</strong><span> Students can learn more about subjects like motion and energy conservation through a number different gameplay scenarios </span></p>

</li>

</ul><p><strong id="docs-internal-guid-91ffde91-6380-ed17-9ce6-77bb7a669a3d"><br/></strong>Educational professionals and students can go to <strong><a href="http://bit.ly/IeFiav">www.kerbaledu.com</a></strong> for more information on the game, which is available on compatible Windows, Mac OS and Linux computers. Schools and other educational institutions interested in <em>KerbalEdu</em> can purchase the educational version of <em>Kerbal Space Program</em> for a discounted price and schools who do decide to use the software will also have the opportunity to offer their students a discounted price on the regular version of <em>Kerbal Space Program</em>.</p>

Congratulations all at Squad who have been negotiating and/or developing this. Another milestone before Christmas :-)

I've often stated that I would REALLY like them to release this as a mod for non-school purposes. There's some good informational stuff here, and it could be used for extracurricular education programs as well.

GJ

If some of those features were added into some kind of a debug mode, that would be cool.

Along with what GJ said, so how does someone who has a consumer-version of KSP get some of these outputs? I'd like to see force arrows and the functions as I'm playing, they sound really fun.

Hell, I'd like some learning scenarios, too.

interesting, but until the aerodynamics are made SLIGHTLY better, i dont consider anything but orbital mechanics to be viable for anyone to learn from. Apparently pancake rockets fly JUST AS WELL as long thin slender ones, WHO KNEW!

Anyways, sarcasm aside, its a nice idea, but i strongly encourage fixing the aerodynamics to be a little better then they are now.
Wow. Seems like those would be some pretty good features. I wouldn't mind it of they were in KSP normally.

Speaking as the Advocatus Diaboli:

This is like asking to get a donut with jelly for free because you bought one with chocolate already.

OK, basically you are asking for some jelly, as both jelly and chocolate come with the same donut, but ... yes?

KerbalEdu took its own amount of work/time/money to make and I am not sure if it is reasonable to expect to get it as a free mod - if it is even as simple as a mod?
